jeopardy_round: WORDS YOU CAN SAY ON TELEVISION

(1, 1).clue: In March 2000 this former Clinton press secretary gave birth to 5-pound, 11-ounce Katherine

(2, 1).clue: Averaging about 74 MPH, Ray Harroun won the first running of this May 30, 1911

(3, 1).clue: "Ask any mermaid you happen to see, 'What's the best tuna?'..."

(4, 1).clue: The Delicious variety of this fruit was first grown in the late 1800s on a farm in Peru, Iowa

(6, 1).clue: Even Disney uses this word, putting it in a title between "That" & "Cat"

(1, 2).clue: A U.S. Coast Guard cutter was named for Harriet Lane, this bachelor president's hostess

(2, 2).clue: Only 2 men have won The Masters 2 years in a row: Nick Faldo & this man

(3, 2).clue: "Everybody doesn't like something, but nobody doesn't like" this

(4, 2).clue: Georgetown, Ohio was named for Georgetown, Kentucky which was named for this man

(6, 2).clue: To fire; if you speak without thinking, you do it "from the hip"

(1, 3).clue: After his wife Rachel died, his niece took over her duties; after she died, a daughter-in-law was summoned

(2, 3).clue: Bob Beamon made his record 29' 2 1/2" long jump in the thin air of this city in 1968

(4, 3).clue: This St. Paul-born author is credited with coining the term "Jazz Age"

(6, 3).clue: It followed "Hong Kong" in the name of a crime-fighting cartoon dog

(1, 4).clue: In July 2000 Hearst hired this reporter who had covered the White House for UPI for 37 years; Thank You, Mr. President

(2, 4).clue: Heavyweight boxing champ in 1974, he went back in the ring in 1994 & regained the title

(3, 4).clue: It's the brand of hot dog that "answers to a higher authority"

(4, 4).clue: Of the 5 Great Lakes, the total number we have to share with Canada

(6, 4).clue: As well as an alteration of the devil's home, it's also an attachment on a loom

(1, 5).clue: Last name of Evelyn, JFK's personal secretary

(2, 5).clue: Basketball history was changed October 30, 1954 with the introduction of this device

(3, 5).clue: "It's not nice to fool Mother Nature"

(4, 5).clue: This "autonomous" Missouri city was the starting point for the Santa Fe, Oregon & California Trails

(6, 5).clue: This 4-letter word is derived from the phrase "od rot" or "God rot"

(1, 1).clue: The title of this Dashiell Hammett novel refers to the chap Nick & Nora Charles are looking for

(2, 1).clue: "The Donkey Show" turns this "dream"y Shakespeare play into "The Ultimate '70s Disco Experience"

(3, 1).clue: In 1921 the United States paid this country $25 million for its loss of Panama 18 years earlier

(5, 1).clue: This element's name is derived from the names of 2 other substances: borax & carbon

(6, 1).clue: The saying "Crazy as" this water bird arose from the strange, laughing calls of the common type

(1, 2).clue: "The Evening Star" is Larry McMurtry's 1992 sequel to this 1975 mother-daughter novel

(2, 2).clue: Winning a Tony for "Little Me", he said, "There are so many people I must thank, but the reality is, I did it all myself":

(3, 2).clue: Tikal & Piedras Negras were major cities of this civilization of northern Guatemala

(5, 2).clue: 2 of the 3 elements named for planets

(6, 2).clue: The silky envelope of an insect that serves as a covering during the pupal stage

(1, 3).clue: The last of his many science fiction novels published during his lifetime was "Chapterhouse: Dune" in 1985

(2, 3).clue: This musical that hit Broadway in 1991 is set partly in Bangkok & partly in Ho Chi Minh City

(4, 3).clue: NBA coach Fitzsimmons or Puritan preacher Mather

(6, 3).clue: It was a gold coin of Spain used during the 1600s

(6, 4).clue: Gene Kelly & Van Johnson discover a magical Scottish village in this film

(2, 5).clue: The 2000 London musical based on this Updike novel stars Lucie Arnaz as the woman Cher played on film
